								OK, It is Early Access game and so its still work in progress. There are some tech issues in joining a match lobby and Devs are working on it and on keyboard controls and further customization. Now is the game good at basic? I think yes. It has potential to be very good and is even now quite fun and I fear addictive. Its Combat arcade meets RPG Fantasy. A Mortal Kombat or Street Fighter in fiery pits of hell and fighters from fantasy epics meets survival. Its simply a fun multiplayer combat game set in RPG mould. I found it simply fun and addictive. Even at early stage its deeply satisfying. Menu is simple and easy to follow. Graphics is quite good. Its a dog eat dog ruthless world. The environment, the players everyone or everything is your enemy. You don't just have to beat the enemy players in rapid deathmatches or the Bosses that jump in simply to kill all, you have to survive also the hostile environment while trying to stay alive and thats both challenging and fun. There are no friends here or even temporary allies to face bigger enemies. You are on your own all the time and anything that can move will certainly kill you. Between friends this will be a kind of extremely fun vs mode, if you are bored of shooting folks down or sniping them in normal vs games. Have fun guys! I look forward to playing this more in coming days.

												This product was given for free to review. tl;drThe game has potential. I suggest grab some friends and play it. Its fun, although it does have its issues. It has a long way to go before I can fully recommend it.tl;drSkara is a medieval PvP RPG action game. There are 3 game modes free for all, deathmatch (which is actually a hard-point type mode) and a duel mode. I played with the Kharn class which was very fun to play, the more you play and level the mode abilities you unlock such as the charge etc. Skara is a strategic game where hits and dodges must be planned before hand, so do not depend on button mashing.. It won't get you very far in this game. The game is stunning to look at, since it was made with Unreal engine - that isn't that hard to believe. There are a few cons with this game but I will get into that later. I feel like this game has a good base, it just needs a push in the right direction.Pros  Looks stunning, the world is just awesome to look at, I played in high settings and it looked gorgeous.  Controls are solid, and you can remap them easily in the menu if you don't like them (I played with the Xbox controller.)  There is a nice range of classes to chose from and a few customization features with in game credits.  The game modes are fun, I liked the deathmatch mode with the hard-point game play. You captured the hard-points and then pillars spawned in the middle for you to defend after a certain amount of time.   The game is easy to pick up but you have to master timing of hits, abilities etc which gives a nice learning curve to it.  The menu is nicely set out and is easy to navigate.Cons  I had some screen tearing issues... But there was no v-sync setting in the graphics tab. Actually there was no in depth graphic settings, only the basic low, medium and high  Controls feel quite clunky at times  This is not the games fault completely but there are very few players... When writing this review there is 4 players in game with a peak of 8... So please find some friends to play with or you will be stuck with the bots  This brings me to my next point which is the AI. The AI needs improving. A lot of the times the AI would be running into walls and not capturing points or attacking when I was capturing.   The game has crashed and black screened my computer resulting in me having to restart my PC.

Early Access Review
								**Edited 9/18/2015I would like to start this review by commending the Development Team for being extraordinarily involved with the community and quite friendly. I asked a question before purchasing the game and the creator of Skara The Blade Remains, cromlech_, responded in a detailed and helpful manner. He then proceeded to invite me to his friend list and took the time to chat with me about my opinion regarding the game. This Dev team seems to be trying really hard to engage the community, be transparent, and take all of our suggestions to heart, and it's wonderful. For anyone interested in Q&A about the game etc., I recommend asking on the forums about when there will be Dev streams on Twitch. After the Q&A they will also be playing the game, so you can watch live footage straight from the Devs. See the TL;DR at the bottom for a short summary of my review. Now, for the actual review- which I will likely edit as I play more of the game, play more characters, and as the game evolves:As you would have likely noted, this game just released in a true Alpha state rather recently(about 3-4 months ago). Currently, since the announcement of true alpha, there has been at least one update a month; the last two updates added a playable tutorial, some new skills, bug fixes, implementation of suggestions by the community such as keybinding etc., This game is still in early Alpha - and I repeat, IT IS EARLY ALPHA. Do not expect a fully fleshed out game yet. The framework is there, and it looks quite promising. It will be free to play in the future, so if you would like to wait until its full release to play, then by all means, please do so. That being said, right now your job if you purchase this game is to test current balance between characters, test maps and game systems, and make suggestions on how to improve the game - because the Devs will listen and almost always respond.General Gameplay - This game has a ton of potential and will be ludicrously fun once all the features are implemented. Right now there are 3 maps, one for each game mode, with plans for more. Some have lava(fall in it and you die) and levers that activate certain map effects. For example, in one map there's a ring in the center that gives way if you hit the lever and this leads to you, or your enemy, tumbling down into a pit of lava. There's also a huge boss-like monster that arises from within the depths of an arena. Currently this monster is an NPC and will attack every player that comes near it - players get extra points for hitting and killing it. A clever player could just stand back as his/her feeble opponents attempt to battle it..and pick them off as they back away in horror. Alas, you will respawn after perishing..so find solace in that.There are 3 game modes. Team deathmatch, free for all, and duel. They are fairly self-explanatory. - I will update this section further the more I play, if I notice any notable deviations. Each character, as you level up, has a set of skills the player can pick. Hold down RT or RB on the gamepad to execute said skills. Shinse has a skill that makes her invisible for a short period of time, and a teleportation ability that switches the player's position with that of his/her target. Also, the devs recently added an ability called, "forest wind," basically you can dash forward in a straight line, damaging any opponents in your path. They also added 1 new skill for the other two currently playable characters, which you can unlock through progressing(leveling up). There are plans to add passive skills and more primary skills.There will be a store where you can buy costumes and weapons with in-game currency as well. These costumes will modify stats. There will be daily quests/missions, factions, gems to modify stats and more in the future. There are placeholders available for them in game already, but they haven't been implemented yet. For new players - There is a playable tutorial right after you create your first character. It explains basic attack, movement, and how to utilize your special attacks. You'll also be able to test out your skills at the end of the tutorial against a few AI opponents.Most of the above systems are fairly barebones at the moment, because, well, it's an early alpha. Once they become more fleshed out, the game will have far more depth. I say that to warn the people expecting some kind of fully fleshed out product, in the hopes that the people purchasing the game will do so knowing that they are helping develop it with their suggestions et al., Combat Gameplay - Each character utilizes a string based on heavy/light attacks. I use an Xbox 360 gamepad so this would be RB and RT. I have played Shinse, thus far. She is a quick assassin-like character.  Her attacks feel appropriately light and heavy depending on what combination of attacks utilized, and they also look nice. Each character can also throw projectiles, a limited number, per life using the A button. Blocking is here too, but blocking attacks drains stamina - and you do NOT want your stamina drained or your block broken as you will be brutally punished by the AI or other players. That being said, the AI so far is kind of placeholder - For example, if you stealth as Shinse the AI will just stand there until you appear again. The last of the controls I will mention here is the "dodge" ability(B on the gamepad), which effectively...dodges. How effective the dodge is depends on your character - some of the heavy characters are a bit slower to dodge. The devs also added 3 new abilities - one for each class, so far I have tried Shinse's out and it is mapped to the X button(again, using a 360 gamepad) by default.Graphics - The game is optimized fairly well for an early alpha, though with recent updates the optimization seems to have gotten a bit worse. That being said, I experienced no notable system lag with all settings maxed. It looks really nice too. I realize "nice" is a vague descriptor, but it's the best I have. To put it another way- this game pleases my ocular orbs.Controls - They are quite responsive. There doesn't seem to be any noticeable input lag. This game does have gamepad (360/Xbox) support as well as keyboard support. The developer has implemented keybindings with update 0.5.3.Community/Online - You'll likely match up against the creative developer and creator of the game if you try out the online. Sadly, the community is fairly small at the moment and you may fight exclusively bots a majority of the time. I hope this changes in the future because these guys deserve both your support and your input as both will help make this game great.So if the game is so early, why do I recommend it? Well, because I really like how involved the Developer is with the community, it shows supreme potential that I have no doubt will be met, and as a barebones early alpha, it's actually pretty fun! TL;DR - Right now you're buying into an early alpha, with an established framework(meaning there's stuff there, like characters, some maps to fight on etc., but it's basic at the moment. Many features still have to be implemented), to help test out balance, make suggestions for improvements, and support the developer. That being said, it's only a $5 buy-in, and it is indeed fun even at this early stage of development. ^_^

								Skara - The Blade Remains is a very interesting project, I am one of the original Kickstarter backers. I like the fact that they keep things minimalistic yet diverse. The game is in early access still so the game is far from being completed. If you’re looking for a well-polished and functional game I wouldn’t recommend the game in its current state. The combat, user interface and some technical issues are the biggest problem right now and they still need a lot of work. 								With the latest update, I am finally actually able to play this game.Before this update: IF I got into a match (crashes happened)(only ever mess with bots, not sure I have a good enough connection to mess with PvP), there was a delay of no less than 15 seconds between hitting an input and finally seeing the action happen.After this update: I can play the game almost as smoothly as is shown in the trailer. I have very high hopes for Skara. Yes, the game is incredibly rough if you consider the devs' ambition, but, seeing the amount of polish put into the game in this one update (i.e. there were no options at all and now there are enough to (maybe) satisfy most (for now)), I am incredibly hopeful. If you approach the game at face-value - as an arena fighter - you, too, will no doubt see only potential and spread the word that "Hey, there's something to this game."[[I am friends with one of the dev's because they friended me after I posted in a discussion, where I complained (before this latest update) that I couldn't play the game. He reassured me that a new update would be coming soon that should take care of it. Skara is, at the moment, an arena fighter, capable of supporting single player versus bots, but meant for PvP. My endorsing of the game might seem like advertisement I was paid to do. It is not. It is simply my recognizing that without a community, Skara could go nowhere. I want this game to be successful. *spreadin' the word*]]Skara definitely seems like a prime example of Early Access done right - invest in the game and watch it get better and better. Currently there are three maps and two characters with three different Armors/Skins (one of these cosmetics is "Coming Soon"). The basics of the fighting system are pretty well done; Skara is not a button-masher, so be decisive in doing what you do (the only complaint that I have with the controls is that the Lock-On (using a controller) seems unresponsive at times) - this is to say that if you get your fighter into a combo, there really doesn't seem to be a way to cancel out of it. Rolling might work, but the camera (whether you're locked-on to an enemy or not) seems to get locked, or at least stiffened, while you're in a combo too. Playing as the Gladiator, I get destroyed by the Assassin, who is much quicker and can teleport (not necessarily hinting that there is a balance issue, because I really think the game is pretty polished thus far - except maybe the fighting being a little too stiff(?)). (Perhaps too) Optimistic (that word usually goes as well with Tynon as "cold" goes with "fire," so hopefully that's a good testament), I think that there is zero chance of Skara being perverted into a bad game that disappoints. The developers truly want to make a great game; they are eager to play with people who post "Multiplayer game with no players?" just waiting for that word of mouth to help Skara take off. With devs as invested as these, yeah, Skara will be big.EDIT: To clarify my "the fighting [is] a little too stiff" comment: Having played the game further, I now have a better feel for what exactly Skara is. It is a deliberate, basic fighter. To elaborate:Have you ever been playing a fighting game and just could not reckon it? There're the 88-fingered wiz's and there are those with, er, an eidetic muscle memory. Thus, there are those who mash buttons in the hope of achieving some awesome combo and there are those who attempt to memorize specific combo's (no doubt just to mix them up and fail). Skara is a deliberate, basic fighter. Though it could be argued that in those other fighting games you've only yourself to blame if you're not good - I think, in that case, it's either a lack of will or manual dexterity. In Skara, it is ONLY up to your ability to anticipate and react. There are no 4-line long combos. There are no cheap Hadoken techniques. So if you're not good at Skara, it's either because of lag in hand-eye coordination or because you're approaching it wrong...My complaining that the combat might be too stiff was misinformed. I was expecting some sort of flighty fighter; Skara is more akin to a heavy-weight chess match. You really do have to plan and counter with the quickness - it's hard (if even possible) to cancel actions so as to reinforce this: If you make a mistake, you will pay. So. If a game of pure skill is what you're after, as opposed to games in which a certain Champion has this one power they keep spamming / a certain Killstreak keeps decimating you / a certain tactic is abused, rendering the game a "Wait out the clock for inevitable defeat because there's no defense from that"... Skara - The Blade Remains

IntroductionI believe this isn't my first review, although it certainly feels like it. Please forgive me if the following review is somewhat disjointed or disorganized in its structure. I would also like to tell you to take both my review and other reviews of this (and any game) with a pinch of salt. What I've written here are, of course, my own opinions. If this game interests you at all after reading this review, you should try it and form your own opinion on it!Skara - The Blade Remains is a multiplayer online team-based battle arena (or perhaps I should call it a fighting game?) with controls and gameplay similar to that of Lords of the Fallen or Dark Souls. You could call it a MOBA with the exceptions of the usual towers and minions that are commonly associated with those kind of games - this is all about the fighting. It is being developed by an independant group (in Spain if I'm not mistaken). It is currently in open alpha testing at the time of this review.So what makes this game good?To be perfectly honest, I went into this game with a clean mind. I had read many of the negative (and positive) reviews and so I decided it would be better to form my own opinion. I was quite surprised by the game, though.Skara has a lot of good elements going for it. While it is not that uncommon to find a third-person MOBA today, I think Skara is one of the only ones that actually has all of its emphasis on the fighting. If you've played a Souls game or something like Dragon's Dogma, you'll get the controls down pretty quickly. Other than your usual WASD-movement controls, your player character has a normal attack and a special attack which they can freely mix into combo attacks. Your character also has a defensive move (for instance, one character can block and another one can counter an attack with the right timing) and the ability to dodge (rolling, stepping or dashing depending on character) which gives you some frames of invincibility. It gives you all the tools necessary for enjoyable (if not a little clunky) intensive fights.Apart from your basic moves, each of the character types have access to three "Signs", or abilities, unique to them. These can be all from throwing your shield while setting it on fire like a pyromaniac Captain America, or placing a trap that encases your enemy (or even yourself or your allies!) in ice so they can't move. These Signs add a lot of versatility to your character and really opens up for interesting tactics, especially during group fights.Skara has two game modes currently, with a third one planned for release soon: A 1v1 duel mode and a 3v3 last man standing mode. The third game mode coming out is a 5v5 domination mode. I actually found it very interesting for a game like this to include a duel mode to begin with, and as such it was the first mode I ever played.The biggest thing that Skara has going for it is how player-driven its development is. Players can post their suggestions and ideas for lore and even character designs and game features, and it is very important that they do so as well. A major part of how the game is played today is because of the feedback the game has received since the beginning of its development. At the time of writing this review, the developers are quickly and happily responding to queries and suggestions on the Steam discussion forums all the time, which is quite impressive.Another large part of Skara is its lore, which does take the player-driven development into account. The previous highest-ranking players were placed as part of the game's lore, for instance. There's a lot to read and a lot to add to the lore, and I don't want to spoil it for you in case you decide to try the game out for yourself, so I think that's all I'll write about it.The game currently has a shop where you can pay real currency to buy cosmetics (and only cosmetics, no pay to win here) for the different characters. The reason I bring this up in this section is because, at least in my opinion, the majority of the cosmetics look really good! I've already spent some money on pimping out my two favorite characters! The graphics overall look very nice and really portrays the overall kind of grim atmosphere.And what makes this game bad?It really depends on your own tastes. As I mentioned, at the time of this writing the game is in open alpha, so there is a lack of content. The duel mode has one map, a frozen little island in the middle of the sea, and the last mand standing mode also only has one map, the lava coliseum. Currently, there are only 4 (with a 5th in the "Coming Soon-making) character types to play with, and even while they are very different from each other, there are indeed only 4.There are bugs, of course. When me and a friend tried to add each other to our friends list or party the first time, it just didn't work - we had to restart the game first. Ever since it has worked though, and when I posted about it on the forums I got a quick reply from one of the developers too. The game is also not very optimized, which is a common thing for an early build, but still might put you off a little if you aren't expecting it. It doesn't slow down dramatically or anything like that, but it can have the occasional stuttering.The matchmaking also seems a bit weird. Even though me and my friend queued up for dueling at the same time, it took the game ~40 seconds of searching for a match before we got to play. It's not a long time, but it is quite strange that it works like that. If you queue up and the game can't find another player, it will pit you against bots until a player takes its/their place.On a final note, I do wish there were more diverse sound effects in the game. The ones that are in are not bad or stock by any means, but how the sound of a spear blade penetrating your flesh is the same sound as a massive pick made out of bone or a curved sword in eastern style is beyond me! It's not gamebreaking though and I imagine this is something that will change as the game develops further.ConclusionSkara - The Blade Remains is a fun game. Fighting other players, especially in last man standing, is a blast and every fight feels different. It is not a perfect game as it lacks content (it is in alpha, after all) but the content it currently has is quite enjoyable. It has been said many times before, but this game has a lot of good potential (and so far it is not being wasted one bit). The only thing Skara really suffers from is a lack of players, and I can't stress that enough - if the game had more active players, it would likely be the one of the games I've invested the most hours in ever on my steam account, haha.Gameplay - 7/10Audio - 7/10Graphics - 8/10Story (Lore) - 6/10I definitely recommend giving this game a try, especially with friends. Thank you for reading!

Early Access Review
OVERVIEWNote: This review was written on 20160906, but could not be posted due to Steam Store Page issues with the game. I've not updated the review since then.Skara - The Blade Remains is an online multiplayer arena fighting game with a fantasy gladiator setting. It's currently in Early Access, but I believe it's very close to release.There's some lore around the character races and setting, but ultimately it's fairly irrelevant to the gameplay, which involves beating opponents to a pulp in short- to medium-length arena combat.GraphicsGraphics in Skara are a bit of a mixed bag. The character graphics and animations are quite good, and the team deathmatch arena looks quite impressive, but the other two arenas and the various special effects are a bit of a letdown.I also noticed heavy motion blur when turning, which both looks a bit meh and also slows down the game noticeably on my gaming laptop (admittedly a fairly old one). Unfortunately there seems to be no way to turn this effect off without lowering the overall graphics detail, as there's only one variable setting available for graphics quality.SoundSkara features fairly typical gladiatorial type battle music, which fits the game well. It's nothing I'd want to listen to outside of the game, but I didn't see any need to turn it off or adjust the volume down.Sound effects, too, are suitable, if nothing out of the ordinary for the genre.GameplayWhen you begin Skara you're given a single character slot and a choice of three races to choose from, each with names that you'll not remember or be able to pronounce unless you're familiar with the world. There's no customisation available unless you use real money to purchase gems to customise your armour, helmet, or weapons, but the developers were wise enough to make these cosmetic only, rather than falling down the pay-to-win rabbit hole. But it does mean that basically all characters of each race look the same, so you'll quickly become used to recognising what's what.There's a brief tutorial that introduces you to the basic moves. Full controller support is available, so I played with an Xbox controller, which worked fine: left stick for movement, right for targeting; triggers for block and basic attacks, B for dodge, and A/X/Y for race-specific attacks, one of which is ranged for each race.The game then drops you on the main screen, from which you can choose to fight in one of three arenas: duel (one on one), free for all (four players, the most kills wins), and team deathmatch (four vs four, a sort of 'hold the fort' type of arena). The most fun and interesting of these by far was the team deathmatch arena, which is well designed and very pretty. The free-for-all arena is reasonable, too, with a trapped area that can be sprung by any player and a 'boss' fighter that is released towards the end to change it up a bit. The one-on-one duels are the most disappointing, and the arena is small and not much fun, with obstacles constantly blocking you in when you try to manoeuvre.Regardless of mode, the game uses an automatic third-person 3D camera that mostly keeps up with action well. I did find myself off camera a few times, and fell to my death multiple times in each arena due to the camera focusing on my targeted enemy and making it hard to keep track of the level dangers.Unfortunately, though, the online-only nature of Skara means that even with a relatively good ADSL2 connection I found the lag unbearable at times. I'd press my assassin character's 'blink' attack button, watch her shoot across the screen and then the game would catch up, teleport her backwards, and drop her right in front of my enemy's swinging blade. Countless times I'd be mid-attack and my target would disappear and reappear out of range behind me somewhere. Even against bots the network code just doesn't seem to cope well enough for an action game like this, where timing is everything.Skara includes character progression through gold and experience points. The former can be used to buy extra abilities, of which there are only very few available, while increases in the latter improves your account level (which is the same across all of your characters), which unlocks extra slots in the game as you progress, giving you space for up to three characters with multiple ability slots. It's a good idea, but as with the game as a whole, it's only fairly limited in scope.Remembering that Skara is still in Early Access, I don't want to be too harsh on it. But something really does need to be done to improve the networking, as lag is a killer in a game like this. Load times, too, are incredibly long; I waited 28 seconds (in-game counter) just for the main screen to disappear after selecting a battle arena type, and then it took about the same time again for the actual lobby to load. Other minor issues include the use of Steam name in some places, even after asking for a different screen name, and terrible grammar in some places. I'm not sure whether the game will include more arena and character variety after release, but I hope so; the choices at the moment are fairly limited.PROS AND CONSPros:+ Fairly good character graphics and animations+ Team deathmatch arena is very pretty, and the game mode is fun+ Free for all arena is interesting and original+ Progression system is a good idea and a good start+ Trading Cards (although as with other F2P games I assume these won't drop after release if you get the game for free)Cons:- Lag makes the 'timing, precision and accuracy' required for intelligent play almost impossible- Very long loading times- It's very easy to fall to your death on any of the arenas- Only three arenas, one of which (ice lake) is rather poor indeed- Limited character selection and customisation (only through purchased gems)- Limited progression limits replayability- Motion blur is annoying- Other minor EA issues (e.g. poor grammar, Steam name used sometimes rather than screen name)CONCLUSIONSkara - The Blade Remains is very hard to not recommend now that it's relatively easily obtainable for free, and will soon be released as free-to-play on Steam. It has its problems, but even when you can't find anyone online it's still fun beating up the bots for a few hours. With more arenas and characters, better loading times, and a big reduction in lag, it would be much better, though.6/10

Strategical thinking and outsmarting the enemy is sometimes essential, because not only your survival and combat skills matter. If your enemies are not careful enough, you wouldn't need to engage in combat, and just use the environment to your advantage. Speaking of combat, the game allows players to free run, or lock on targets. Locking on targets is a must for best precision. Sometimes locking on targets unlocks passive abilities - like fast dashing, or running jump spear strike. Some characters have passive abilities, like shield defense. Dive into this clash combat adventure in 1v1, 3v3 or 5v5 modes, each one on a different map, with different environmental rules. Early Access Review
								To start, I had a LOT of trouble getting this game to load (it would be nearly two months before I got to finally try the game). Once I had the chance to try it, I saw why everyone was reinforcing the "Early Access" Label. It is an Early Access release, but while it seems to still need a lot of work it also has good potential and has some fairly active developers - so it seems promising to follow.The game is an FFA/DM multiplayer arena fighter with a neat collaborative boss to fight at the end (so far only available in one particular level - I suspect the other levels will also have a collaborative boss eventually). Graphically, the game has the effects and character design and landscaping of a promising game; it's really pretty. My immediate thoughts from previews and screenshots was actually reminiscent of Vindictus by Nexon/DevCat - the theme and scale feels similar in some ways and I rather liked that. The animations and mechanics still feel a bit clunky and restrictive of the player's options to adapt to a fight. A lot of the attack options you have are very linear and in-flexible and you can't intentionally interrupt them very well without cancelling the attack entirely. Additionally, once you are beyond a certain point into the attack animation, you kind of lose control of your character (so if your attack missed, you basically become fodder for spam attacks from the swarming bots as your character slowly recovers from the attack cool down).After a lot of practice, you might finally familiarize with enough of the animation procedures and timing mechanics to be somewhat effective in battle (or maybe discover an exploit similar to how the bots can spam you once you are knocked down) - however it feels more like a game about timing events based on your familiarity with particular model animations still. It doesn't feel oriented around counter attacking or flexible and dynamic attacks. The male character has a clear advantage using a spear/polearm for their fast attack that easily outranges the dagger fast attack of the female character. Sure the female character can throw daggers and use a charge attack, however both have larger vulnerabilities and skill requirements that make them less effective than the ranged fast attack of the spear. I mentioned "[exploiting mechanics to win]" and that was the first one I quickly discovered and relied on.The Arenas are rather big, but not entirely purposeful during fights yet. Once you are in a conflict with a bot, the rest of the Arena outside of attack range is just space that you are not using (unless you manage to dodge and sprint away, but even still that doesn't give the arena's scale much purpose)------------Like everyone says, it's still in Early Access. It does look like it has potential, but in it's current state it's very hard for me to recommend it yet as enjoyably playable. However, I would recommend following it as development progresses.If I could make one request, it would be to expand the graphical settings to be more advanced. I had to play on low quality settings because one of the effects that automatically kicks on from Medium and higher quality consistently plays at nearly the same, very low fps. I suspect it's V-sync or aliasing maybe. Either way, it would be nice to break down the graphical settings to be more customizeable so I don't need to sacrifice all the other graphical features because of one or two particular settings not workign well on my GPU.

Early Access Review
								This game isn't bad, but there's nothing to call all that fantastic either. I don't feel it's unfair to compare the combat to Dark Souls PvP, just without anywhere near as much polish or customization options outside of four character archetypes. The fighting has a deliberate pacing that could make it very solid for mindgames and countering, but everything feels a bit too clunky to execute any strategies with precision.All customization so far is cosmetic. Aside from a few freebies like the spearman's first helmet, it's all locked behind a paywall. Character and account levels contribute nothing aside from being a rough gauge of how long someone has played or how much they've won. An interesting thing to note at least, is the page that just displays and explains each character's moves in a card format. I'm assuming the developers are trying to impliment an ability card system, but there's nothing else of substance to this aside from said page.Oh yeah, and get used to bot matches, since I don't think anyone else is playing this game much.

Be awared, it really requires that much.The game is actually good, the battle system flows well and the characters do seem responsive to your commands, although they aren't really charismatic at all. The graphics are nice also and it looks pretty good. The game apparently has some cool customization, like passive skills. I say apparently because the game is still not fully launched yet, it lacks some things in it that are with a "coming soon" sign. The game may be a pretty good arena fighting game. Also, the controls are pretty easy to get into, even in the keyboard+mouse.But, since it requires a lot to play, the game doesn't have a large pool of players. It lacks players, it is hard to find players to play this game. And the bots become boring.Maybe they can still improve the game and get over these problems, maybe putting better AI or a single player system, but requiring that much, it can still be a problem for it, it actually makes it a pretty niche game.I recommend this game, it is not bad, it just have some problems to improve.
